questionListItems.title: What should employees do if they have already declared their employment income and deductions, and their employers have also submitted their income information via the AIS?

answer.body:
If your employees have e-Filed their Income Tax Return, they may re-file their tax returns at myTax Portal (Individuals > File Income Tax Return) within 7 days of their previous submission or by 18 Apr, whichever is earlier.

If your employees have received their tax bill (i.e. Notice of Assessment), they may file an amendment using the 'Object to Assessment' digital service at myTax Portal within 30 days from the date of the tax bill.

topics.title: AIS - Inform Employees to File Tax Returns

questionListItems.title: I had stamped on a 2-year tenancy agreement. However, the tenancy period was changed to 1 year instead. Can I get a stamp duty refund?

answer.body:
Stamping is required if a new agreement was executed to effect the change.


However, if you had canceled the previous agreement, no refund can be allowed if the instrument has been made use of.


An instrument is considered 'made use of' if any of the parties to the instrument has enforced his/her rights under the instrument or has in any way acted on the terms of the instrument.


Examples of this include when payment has been made, a deposit has been forfeited, compensation has been obtained, possession of the property has been taken, or the lease term has commenced.

questionListItems.title: I am a foreigner, and my spouse is a US Citizen. Is ABSD payable if we were to purchase a residential property?

answer.body:
ABSD remission under the Free Trade Agreement will apply if the individual is a citizen of the United States of America (US). He/She will receive the same Stamp Duty treatment as Singapore Citizens.


Therefore, if an individual who is a US citizen jointly purchases a residential property with his/her spouse, the ABSD Spouses Remission may be applicable. ABSD will be remitted if all conditions are met, and they do not own any other residential property.

questionListItems.title: I had earlier stamped my tenancy agreement and need to make amendments. How do I amend the lease start date?

answer.body:
To amend the lease start date of the tenancy period, please provide a copy of the Tenancy Agreement for our review by following these steps:


1. Log in to myTax Portal under "Stamp Duty".

2. Click on "Inbox" and select "Compose Mail".

3. Input the Document Reference No. before proceeding with your request for amendment.


You do not need to submit a new stamping or revise the stamping record done previously if the lease period has not commenced, and you bring forward or defer the lease without changes in lease term and gross rent.

questionListItems.title: How do I log in to the e-Stamping portal as a Business User?

answer.body:
To access the e-Stamping Portal as a Business User, you must first be authorised under Corppass for a "Corporate" Role.


Once authorised under Corppass, please follow these steps to register for an e-Stamping Account:

1. Log in to myTax Portal under Stamp Duty as a Business User.

2. Click on "Account" > select "Register a New Account".

3. An Assigned ID will be generated instantly upon successful registration (Assigned ID typically starts with AXXXXXXXXY - X refers to numeric, Y refers to alphabet).

4. Reauthorize the relevant individuals or yourself under Corppass for e-Stamping services using the Assigned ID (AXXXXXXXXY) generated.


Refer to the guide for Account Registration for more information. If you need assistance in adding/amending authorized roles for e-stamping services in Corppass, please contact Corppass at 6335 3530.

questionListItems.title: I intend to sell my current private property (of which I am the sole owner) and buy another private property under my sole name. If the buyer exercises the option to purchase, is there a grace period before I can purchase another residential property without incurring ABSD?

answer.body:
If a contract or an agreement to purchase the property has been signed, that property is considered to be acquired by the buyer and sold by the seller.


Hence, if a Singapore Citizen purchases a residential property after the contract or agreement for sale of his/her current property is executed, and he/she does not own any other residential property, ABSD is not payable.


For non-Singapore Citizens, they will be considered as purchasing their first property, and the relevant ABSD rate is applicable.

questionListItems.title: I am a single Singapore Citizen and currently own a condominium unit. If I buy a resale HDB flat, do I have to pay ABSD?

answer.body:
For Singapore Citizens purchasing an HDB flat (including a resale flat) or a New EC, Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) is remitted. More information is available under "Acquisition of HDB Flats and New Executive Condominium (EC) Units".


1. Remission is granted automatically upon HDB's approval of the acquisition.

2. Remission is not applicable for Resale EC.

questionListItems.title: How should I stamp a Novation Agreement or an Assignment of Lease to a new Landlord instead of to a new Tenant?

answer.body:
For an assignment of lease to a new landlord, stamp duty is chargeable on the consideration, if any, at the BSD rates. If there is no consideration paid, stamp duty is not applicable. 


If you are unsure whether your agreement is subject to stamp duty, please submit your document for our assessment through the e-Stamping Portal by following these steps:


1. Go to myTax Portal and click on "Stamp Duty".

2. Log in as an Individual User or Business User.

3. Click on “Requests” in the top navigation bar.

4. Select “Apply for Assessment/Appeal”.


Upon successful submission, you will receive a case reference number, and you will be notified once the review is completed.

questionListItems.title: I have stopped renting out my property. Why is it still taxed at the non-owner-occupier residential tax tates?

answer.body:
When the lease on your property ends and you have moved back into your home, you have to reapply for the owner-occupier tax rates for your property using ‘Apply/Withdraw for Owner-Occupier Tax Rates’ - digital service.


If the lease is pre-terminated, please apply for the owner-occupier tax rates by writing to us with supporting documents to show that the lease has been pre-terminated. You may refer to the section above on “Applying for owner-occupier tax rates” for some examples of supporting documents that you can provide to show that the lease has been pre-terminated.

questionListItems.title: I relocated overseas for work purpose. Can the owner-occupier tax rates (OOTR) still apply on my residential property which is my default residence in Singapore?

answer.body: If you (the property owner) reside outside of Singapore temporarily for official or business purposes, OOTR can still be applied so long as your residential property is maintained as your home and is not rented out.

questionListItems.title: Our late brother's property was rented out prior to his passing. As the tenancy has ended, can we apply for the owner-occupier tax rates (OOTR)?

answer.body: As the owner-occupier tax rates were not applied on the residential property prior to the owner’s passing (i.e. the property was rented out or vacant), the concession is not applicable, and the property will continue to be taxed at the non-owner-occupier residential tax rates. Please arrange to have the property legally transferred to the beneficiaries. IRAS will review the OOTR based on the new owner’s eligibility.

questionListItems.title: We have been trying hard to sell my deceased brother's residential property, but we are unable to get a buyer and the house is currently vacant. Can IRAS continue to apply the lower owner-occupier tax rates for this property?

answer.body: For residential properties held under deceased ownership, IRAS will extend the concessionary rates for a period of two years from date of the owner’s demise to allow some time for the property transfer/sale arrangements to be made before the non-owner-occupier residential tax rates are applied.

questionListItems.title: I reside in property (A) while my wife resides in property (B). Are the owner-occupier tax rates allowed to be applied on both properties?

answer.body: Under the Property Tax Act, when 2 owners are married to each other, you can only apply the owner-occupier tax rates to 1 owner-occupied home, regardless of whether it is owned jointly or separately by both of you.

questionListItems.title: My residential property is owner-occupied after completion/TOP obtained, but I have been billed for non-residential tax rates. How do I revise my tax rates?

answer.body:
If the property has obtained TOP, please let us have the following:

(a) A copy of Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP)/Certificate of Statutory Completion (CSC), whichever is earlier (Please indicate if it is a direct CSC)
(b) Site area of the land plot

(c) Gross floor area of the property
(d) A copy of the constructed floor plans in A4 size (please ensure that the floor plans are clear and the wordings in the plans are of readable font size.)


IRAS will review the assessment on the new building after receiving the required information and the owner-occupier tax rates will be granted once the assessment on the new building is finalised. You may also request your architect to submit the relevant information to us directly.

questionListItems.title: My co-owner and I own 50% of the shares of the property respectively. Can IRAS split the property tax amount and send separate bills to each of us instead?

answer.body: The property tax bill will be issued to the owner who is listed first in the Notice of Transfer filed by the seller's lawyer. The payment arrangement on the property tax payable is a private matter to be settled among the property owners. We are unable to issue separate bills.
